citations.narrative:
During a public feeding interaction, an employee was observed instructing a participant to feed one of two tigers with a
feeding pole approximately 4 ft. in length. The end of the feeding pole had a metal barbeque fork with two relatively sharp
points, (to spear the meat), fastened to the pole and there was no disc or flange mounted on the pole to prevent it from
being pulled or pushed through the enclosure fence.
After the employee loaded a chunk of raw meat on the feeding pole, it was offered by the participant, (standing behind a 3
ft. barrier railing), to the tiger through a small open plastic disc placed in front of the standard chain link fence. On the
second feeding, the participant extended her hand past the barrier railing and was admonished by the employee. This
pole-feeding process was observed four times at the time of the inspection
Current guidance states that the above method of public feeding does not adequately minimize the risk of harm to assure
the safety of the animals and the public as the tiger could attempt to pull the pole into the enclosure and potentially harm
itself on its sharp points or a person could push the pole through the disc and into the enclosure, potentially injuring the
tiger.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by November 30, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility staff.
